ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: history knowledge and inspirations for the Hellenistic history which I didn't know that much before

Writing analytical history essays and learning about the hellenistic period. An exciting world that is under-appreciated by many as a period in between the classical Greek period and the Roman Empire.
- some specific facts about wars/people/events during the Hellenistic period, and a lot about the general trends of life during this period
Learned a lot of very cool facts about the hellenistic period. Provides a very interesting historical comparison to consider our present society.
Honestly, not many skills as a senior history major. I did gain lots of understanding about the Hellenistic world, and that's pretty cool!

Historical analysis particularly with an eye to primary sources. I learned a lot about the fascinating period of Hellenistic historyincluding the fates of Central Asia, India, and Israel in this time. I can now quote Polybius and Diodorus from memory.
the hellenistic world
Learned about the Hellenistic world.
I learned about the history and culture of the Hellenistic World. I refined my essay writing skills.
History of Alexander the great

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
the class is interactive and the lectures are informative and helpful. overall this is a great class!

would be better that if we could watch more interesting videos or interviews in TA discussion sessions. 

Would recommend the professor to arrange outdoor classes on the lawn outside the building if the weather approves.
Exciting material, but the readings are long and not super manageable for some weeks.

Strengths:
- super chill, the assessments are very straightforward and easygoing 
- very enthusiastic professor and TA

Weaknesses:
- sometimes the lectures went a bit off track of the main point to the point that I would have maybe liked a bit more structure to them, but overall, it was still enjoyable/interesting/I learned a lot
Make sure to pay attention during lecture, because it's difficult to follow the slides on their own without Professor Manning's commentary.

The lectures are... disorganized. And Prof Manning is a great guy but he's just a little all over the place, which couldn't really be helped (nor do I think he really cares). The concept of the course itself is pretty interesting, but I wish we can have a clearer timeline/map or anything spatial to help us understand the events and their spaces?
Professor Manning is awesome... great professor who cares about the success of students and building relationships!
strength: content
The course content is interesting and the professor is great and knowledgeable. The lectures were a little unorganized sometimes though.

this course suffered from the amount of texts assigned - it is almost impossible for a student with a full course load to read several hundreds of texts a week, especially when little to none of those texts are present on the exams.

The course covered interesting material and the professor was excited about it. However, Professor Manning was only interested in parts of the material meant to be included in the scope of the class. I would have preferred a more even handed look at history. For example, Professor Manning on the day dedicated to discussion women in the Hellenistic world, mentioned how to most important woman was likely Arsinoe II and then spent the rest of the class talking about Cleopatra. While it was certainly interesting, it was also frustrating knowing that there was this whole other topic, more critical to the broad path of history, that we didnt discuss. There are many more examples like this. Overall, I think the course had good spirit, but was hurt by the lack of organization or a cohesive plan for the semester.
No weakness

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes - I would recommend this class to any people interested in western history.
Yes, it's a great ancient history class.

If you're looking for a chill 5th credit AND/OR if you're very interested in classical and hellenistic history, then yes! it's not the most fun class if you don't already have an interest in the material, but with a bit of reviewing, you can do well on the assessments and enjoy the class as well
Yes, it's pretty interesting! A nice, unique fifth class that's not overly busy.

Well, if you want to learn about something new. But honestly, if you're looking for an organized lecture, this is not your class. I honestly learned more from reviewing for the exams than from what I remember from the lectures - because they're so disorganized and I barely remember anything after a while.
Yes, provided they have a modicum of interest in the Greek, Persian, Egyptian, or Hebrew world.
Yes.. Professor Manning is a goat and worth taking any class regardless of what the course material is if he is the professor
yes
Yes I would recommend it  its a nice, chill history class.
Yes
Its a history gut.
Yes - fantastic course, fantastic professor
Yes, if they were interested in a good overview of Hellenistic history.
Yes
